factText: The Midland Community Television (MCTV) broadcasting and live streaming video services will be unavailable until further notice due to flooding.

Midland County, Mich., Implements Flood Plan after Dam Failure - Government Technology https://t.co/GWkoQwbgaX #dam https://t.co/4XF3wmDjeL. The big "clean up" underway in #Midland after devastating dam failures.

Four Midland County homeowners have filed a class action lawsuit against the state of Michigan seeking damages and other relief after the Edenville Dam failure. Four Midland County homeowners have filed a class action lawsuit against the State of Michigan Department of Environment, Great Lakes and Energy (EGLE) seeking damages and other relief for its mismanagement of the Edenville Dam.
informationNeeds: CrisisFACTS-013_Flood_What is the estimated damage to infrastructure due to {event}?

factText: Four Midland-area residents have filed a class-action lawsuit in state court against the Michigan Department of Environment, Great Lakes and Energy regarding its oversight of the Edenville Dam, arguing that its actions "caused .. serious property damages and economic harm."
informationNeeds: CrisisFACTS-013_general_How are businesses and local economies affected by {event}?

factText: Four homeowners in Midland County have filed a class action lawsuit against the state alleging mismanagement and neglect of the now-failed Edenville Dam. Developing News - Four Midland homeowners have filed a class action lawsuit against Michigan's Department of Environment, Great Lakes and Energy seeking damages and other relief resulting from last week's failure of the Edenville Dam. Stunning footage of Michigan's Edenville Dam as it failed to hold back floodwaters on Tuesday, May 19, 2020.

factText: "Entire neighborhoods were literally swept away in Sanford after the Edenville dam broke—the entire Tittabawassee floodplain impacted people all the way along it, from people along Wixom lake who suddenly have no lake anymore to those in Sanford and Midland who are having to rebuild their homes for the second time in three years."
informationNeeds: CrisisFACTS-013_Flood_Which areas are most affected by flooding during {event}?

factText: The Sanford Centennial Museum and Midland County Historical Society are dealing with a terrible loss—flood damage from the dam failures on the Tittabawassee River have left these two member organizations with destroyed artifacts, damaged pieces, and urgent building issues.

factText:
The Edenville Dam failed and apparently caused the breach of the Sanford Dam in Midland County last week. After Edenville Dam failure, lawsuits pour in against owners, state regulators https://t.co/ZGryj3nnNh. Michigan Dem winning -

The Four Lakes Task Force said in a statement: "The Lake Associations and Counties were in the process of acquiring the dams, with a closing expected, and then to improve the dams to survive historic floods.
Road closures continue across Midland County

Distribution and resource sites are opening on Wednesday, May 27 to help Midland County residents who have been impacted by the recent floods. Help is on the way for devastated residents who are still coming to terms with the scale of damage left behind after the catastrophic flooding. In collaboration with United Way of Midland County and Midland's Emergency Operations Center, a process has been created for flood relief.

factText: He reported road closures due to flooding: *Cranberry Lake Road between Rodgers and Athey was washed out; *Bear Road between Lily Lake and Clarence had a culvert washed out; *Stockwell between Athey and Rodgers had a culvert washed out; *Athey between Dover and Browns Road; *Maple Grove between Old State and M-115; *Arnold Lake between Garfield and Kirby; *Pine between Twin Lakes and Partridge; and *Partridge between Forest and Pine.

factText: See the scene as Michigan towns evacuate after dams fail https://t.co/6kOmAKhMw6. Last week, two dams in Michigan failed after heavy rains and flooding, forcing 11,000 people to evacuate while trying to social distance. Satellite images show swaths of Midland County, Michigan underwater following two dam failures near Edenville. @MichiganDNR is assisting in removing people and their pets from Midland County areas ravaged by the dam flooding.
Oceana County Dispatch has reported a road washout near Harrison Road and 160th Ave west of Walkerville.

The Baptist State Convention of Michigan is also challenged because many flood evacuees are refusing to enter shelters where disaster relief volunteers can most easily respond to their needs and concerns.

factText: The flooding in Midland last week was devastating.  . Heavy rains and dam failure caused  flooding in communities across #Michigan. A video captured by a viewer shows the moment the Edenville Dam breached, causing historic flooding in Midland County on Tuesday.

Dam failures in Michigan’s Midland County led to the evacuation of thousands, and a state of emergency declared by Governor Gretchen Whitmer. Wednesday, two dam breaches in Michigan caused severe flooding, forcing thousands of residents to evacuate and threatening a major toxic cleanup site. Class action lawsuits allege failure and neglect by dam operators and the state led to flooding that displaced 11,000 people. Multiple friends were impacted by the dam break in MI.

Debate over the allegations comes against a backdrop of Whitmer’s continued lockdown orders in the state and her insistence last week, citing health concerns, that residents not flood northern Michigan’s recreational areas over the holiday weekend.
informationNeeds: CrisisFACTS-013_general_Are evacuation orders still in place or have they been lifted?

factText: Some of the items needed are: drinking water, bleach and cleaning supplies. Also needed are clean, gently used clothes and shoes.

It could be days before the full scope of rampaging waters that submerged houses, washed-out roads, and threatened a dangerous toxic site is apparent, authorities warned last week. Gladwin County is still working to recover from devastating flooding last week. dams and levies break flooding entire towns.
